title: Human Embryonic Stem Cells as a Model for Hematopoietic Stem Cell Differentiation and Viral Infection
procedures:
Maintenance of hESCs is essential to keep cells undifferentiated and provide a consistent source of cells for reproducible experiments. hESCs are cultured on a Matrigel substrate in defined medium with daily medium changes to prevent cell toxicity and maintain constant levels of nutrients and growth factors. Sterile technique is essential, as cells are typically cultured in media free of antibiotics and antifungals to improve cell growth and minimize spontaneous differentiation. Cultures should be checked at each medium change to monitor the health of the cells and the growth of cell aggregates. Quality-control testing for tissue culture of primary and/or sensitive cells, including regular mycoplasma, microbiological, and endotoxin testing and reagent validation, and regular training updates, among other measures, should be included if not already part of standard practice. Healthy cells have a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio; are adherent, with smooth edges; and exhibit rapidly increased growth after several days in culture. hESCs in this protocol are maintained as aggregates (Fig. 1B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-fig-0001]) to promote expansion and suppress spontaneous differentiation. Although hESCs can be grown either as aggregates or as single cells (easier for cell counting and essential for generating clonal cell lines), aggregate growth supports a consistent cell phenotype, prevents the development of abnormal clones, and is required for long-term maintenance and robust initiation of hematopoietic differentiation (see Basic Protocol 2[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0002]).
Materials

Matrigel, hESC qualified (Corning, cat. no. 35427; aliquot according to manufacturer's instructions; store at −20°C)
DMEM/F12 medium (Gibco, cat. no. 11320-033), 4°C
hESCs [e.g., cells used in our study: WA01 (H1) NIH registry #0043 (WiCell, cat. no. WA01 [mTeSR Plus/Matrigel]) and WA09 (H9), NIH registry #0062 (WiCell, cat. no. WA09 [mTeSR Plus/Matrigel])]
Dry ice
Dulbecco's phosphate-buffered saline (DPBS), without calcium and magnesium (Corning, cat. no. 21-031-CV; store at room temperature)

ReLeSR (STEMCELL Technologies, cat. no. 05873; store at room temperature)
15- and 50-ml conical tubes
6-well tissue culture plates
37°C water bath
5-, 10-, and 25-ml serological pipets
Tissue culture centrifuge (with buckets that can hold 15- and 50-ml conical tubes)
Tissue culture microscope (inverted microscope with 4×, 10×, and 20× objectives; Nikon Ti2 or equivalent)
Additional reagents and equipment for freezing cells (see Support Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0004], steps 1 to 11; optional)
Preparation
1. Thaw mTeSR1 supplement at 4°C overnight or at room temperature until just thawed.
2. Aliquot appropriately in 50-ml conical tubes and store at −20°C.
A useful aliquot size is 10 ml supplement aliquoted into a 50-ml conical tube.
3. Prepare complete mTeSR1 medium by combining cold mTeSR1 basal medium with supplement at a 4:1 ratio.
Coating plates with Matrigel
4. Thaw a Matrigel aliquot on ice.
Choose an aliquot size appropriate for the number of wells needed.
When preparing to either thaw cells or split cells, coat plates with Matrigel. In this protocol, all hESC culture steps (passage, testing, differentiation) are performed in 6-well plates with 1 ml Matrigel coating solution per well.
5. Aliquot 1 ml cold DMEM/F12 medium per well into a 15- or 50-ml conical tube and place on ice.
6. Add 500 μl cold DMEM/F12 to the thawed Matrigel aliquot (of any size) and quickly but thoroughly mix by pipetting. Then, transfer to the conical tube containing the remaining DMEM/F12.
7. Mix the Matrigel + DMEM/F12 mixture by inverting the tube.
8. Plate 1 ml Matrigel + DMEM/F12 per well of a 6-well tissue culture plate.
9. Rock the dish to completely cover the wells.
10. Incubate at room temperature for 1 hr to allow Matrigel to solidify on the well surface.

Do not exceed 3 hr of incubation and do not let plates dry out.
Proceed to step 11 during the incubation.
Thawing hESCs
11. Before starting cell culture, warm complete mTeSR1 medium from step 3 to room temperature.
Do not use a water bath to warm the medium.
If feeding only 1 to 2 wells of cells, aliquot the complete medium into smaller volumes (∼10 ml) to avoid repeated warming of larger medium volumes.
12. Identify the batch of hESCs to be used and determine the optimal number of wells needed per vial of frozen cells.
The optimal number of wells for each vial of frozen cells is based on aggregate number and is either provided in the information included with commercially obtained cells or determined experimentally after banking cell batches (see Support Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0004]).
13. Remove Matrigel + DMEM/F12 solution from the pre-coated well(s) from step 10 by aspiration and proceed immediately to step 14.
14. Add 1 ml complete mTeSR1 medium to each Matrigel-coated well.
15. Remove needed number of hESC vials from liquid nitrogen using standard safety precautions. Place vials on dry ice and transfer to tissue culture room.
16. Thaw vial(s) by quick immersion in a 37°C water bath with constant swirling until only a small ice piece remains.
17. Prepare 10 ml cold DMEM/F12 in a 15-ml conical tube (with a separate tube for each vial of cells) and use it to wash freezing medium off the hESCs:
         
a.Using a 5-ml serological pipet, add 1 ml cold DMEM/F12 dropwise to the hESC vial.
Here and in steps 17b to 17d, be careful not to break up aggregates.
b.Gently draw entire contents of the vial into the pipet and add dropwise to the 15-ml conical tube containing the remaining 9 ml DMEM/F12.

c.Draw up 2 ml new cold DMEM/F12 and rinse the vial. Transfer slowly (but faster than dropwise) to the 15-ml conical tube to resuspend the cells.
d.Cap tube and invert gently once to mix.
The final volume is now 14 ml (10 ml DMEM/F12 plus 2 ml cells in freezing medium plus 2 ml additional DMEM/F12).
18. Spin down cells for 5 min at 300 × g at room temperature and decant off medium.
19. Resuspend cells gently in complete mTeSR1 medium (1 ml per well of a 6-well plate) using a 5-ml serological pipet.
Pipet gently and carefully and use a 5-ml serological pipet (which has a wider bore than a micropipet tip) to avoid breaking up aggregates.
20. Gently add cells to the prepared Matrigel-coated plates (see step 14) by adding 1 ml cell aggregate/medium suspension to each well.
21. Place plates in the incubator and distribute aggregates evenly across the surface and incubate for 24 hr.
To distribute, leave the plate sitting flat on the incubator shelf and move the plate quickly using back-and-forth and side-to-side motions to minimize settling of cells in the center of the wells.
IMPORTANT NOTE: Be sure not to disturb the cells for the next 24 hr. Minimize vibrations from nearby equipment and the force of opening/closing the incubator door.
The following section assumes that day 1 is the day immediately following the day the cells were split or thawed.
Maintenance of hESC cultures
Day 1
22. Warm complete mTeSR1 medium from step 3 to room temperature (2 ml per well of cells).
23. Remove cells from the incubator (see step 21).
Do not remove more than two plates at a time to minimize exposure of the cells to ambient temperatures, as hESCs spontaneously differentiate if the temperature fluctuates.

24. Check cells on one plate for aggregate adherence, aggregate number, and aggregate dispersal using a tissue culture microscope.
Aggregate assessment varies depending on the day post-thaw/post-split and the intended use. See Table 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-tbl-0001] for specifics and Figure 1B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-fig-0001] for example plating density. The ideal number of aggregates depends on application (hESC maintenance vs. differentiation of hESCs to HPCs; see Basic Protocol 2[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0002] and Fig. 3[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-fig-0003]). Maintenance of hESCs is more flexible than differentiation, and an initial aggregate density of about 100 to 500 aggregates per well is usable following the guidelines in steps 33 to 35.

30. Check cells for aggregate condition (adherence, number, and dispersal) and for signs of spontaneous differentiation.

See Figures 1C[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-fig-0001] and 1D[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-fig-0001] for example images of large normal aggregates and spontaneous differentiation. Spontaneous differentiation is normal in hESC cultures at a rate of <2% of total aggregates and can be used as a quick surrogate for pluripotency. However, excess spontaneous differentiation (>5% of total aggregates or occurring every passage), visualized by the appearance of endothelial-like cells or spiky protrusions from the edges of aggregates (Fig. 1D[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-fig-0001], yellow circle), indicates an unhealthy culture.
31. Estimate aggregate number and size.
The overall aggregate number will influence the passage date (more aggregates will require an earlier passage even though the aggregate size will be smaller, as a more crowded well will have aggregates that begin to merge earlier), and this will influence the passage timing and ratio. Aggregate size will also influence passage timing (a plate with few but very large aggregates will also require an earlier passage, as cells in the center of a large aggregate have less nutrient accessibility and reduced physical space for growth, resulting in senescence and cell death).
32. Estimate upcoming passage date based on aggregate density.
Cells should be passaged when aggregates are densely packed but not completely merged. Merged aggregates essentially function as extra-large aggregates, with the same reduction in cell health (see step 31). Note that aggregates grow quicker at later dates from passaging and can rapidly expand from one day to the next near the end.
33. Feed or passage cells as appropriate.
To feed, follow steps 22 to 28. To passage (or split), see steps 34 to 46.
Passaging hESCs
34. Determine split ratio of the cells by estimating (or counting; see Support Protocol 2[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0005]) the number of aggregates and the size of the aggregates present.

The split ratio is determined both by the number of aggregates you obtain after splitting the cells (estimated based on aggregate size and density, the specifics of the handling technique, and the amount of spontaneous differentiation present and verified with the actual aggregate count post-split) and by the intended downstream use for the cells (see below). Specifics within the suggested range should be empirically determined.
For expansion or banking of cells, use a 1:10 to 1:50 split ratio. For expanding cells for hematopoietic differentiation, use a 1:10 to 1:20 ratio. For freezing cells, use a 1:5 to 1:10 ratio.
35. Prepare new Matrigel-coated plates for passaging as above (see steps 4 to 10) or prepare for freezing cells (see Support Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0004], steps 1 to 11).
36. Warm complete mTeSR1 medium from step 3 to room temperature (1 ml per well to harvest plus enough medium for plating or freezing).
37. Remove one plate from the incubator and aspirate medium from the wells.
Work with just one plate at a time, as it is critical to not let the plates dry out.
38. Wash wells with 1 ml DPBS and aspirate wash.
Gently add PBS down the side of the wells without disturbing the aggregates.
39. Add 1 ml ReLeSR per well and aspirate all ReLeSR within 1 min.
This leaves a thin (invisible) film of liquid over the cells.
ReLeSR is an enzymatic solution used to detach aggregates or cells from Matrigel-coated plates. ReLeSR is stored and used at room temperature.

A good time for ReLeSR incubation is the time it takes to add 1 ml liquid to five additional wells (i.e., if you are processing a whole 6-well plate, add ReLeSR to each well and then remove the ReLeSR from the wells in order, without rushing; if you are processing fewer than six wells, mentally mimic processing the other wells to space out the timing.
40. Incubate the plate after ReLeSR removal at 37°C for 5 to 7 min.
The incubation time varies depending on (1) the individual user (even after training), (2) the incubator (even with frequent calibration), and (3) the aggregate size and density (larger and denser aggregates will take longer to remove). A good practice is to place the plate in the incubator for 4.5 min and then remove it and check under the microscope for loosening of aggregates (aggregate edges should be compacted, and cells should be retracted into the body of the aggregate). Incubate longer as needed, with continual monitoring under the microscope at room temperature. Reference images of aggregates at different times during ReLeSR incubation can be found in the ReLeSR manual from STEMCELL Technologies.
41. Add 1 ml complete mTeSR1 medium per well to stop ReLeSR action.
42. Detach colonies by gentle but firm tapping on the sides of the plate.
Hold the plate firmly in one hand and tap the side of the plate using the other hand. Then, rotate the plate and repeat the tapping on each of the remaining sides, distributing the force equally across the plate. Empirically determine the number of times to tap the plate. A good starting point is 8 to 13 times per side, resulting in release of ∼95% of all aggregates without reducing individual aggregate size more than 50%.

43. If working with multiple wells, use a 5-ml serological pipet to transfer all cell aggregates to a 15- or 50-ml conical tube. Pipet up and down once when all cells are transferred to the conical to get even distribution of aggregates in solution and help homogenize aggregate size.
Optional: Check that the cell aggregates are appropriately sized by counting the aggregates and/or individual cells as described in Support Protocol 2[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0005]. If aggregates are too big, pipet gently to break up.
IMPORTANT NOTE: It is very important that aggregates are at the appropriate size (50 to 200 μm; Fig. 1B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-fig-0001]) and of the appropriate number for passaging. For troubleshooting aggregate size, see Table 2[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-tbl-0002].
44. Repeat steps 37 to 43 for all remaining plates to be harvested.
45. Plate cells at the desired density on the prepared plates from step 35 or freeze cells as in Support Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0004], steps 1 to 11.
The desired density should be such that cultures can be split every 4 to 7 days and is usually a 1:10 to 1:50 split. If the cells were too dense or too sparse at the last split, adjust the split ratio accordingly.
46. Place plate back in the incubator, evenly distribute cells (see step 21), and leave undisturbed for 24 hr.

Differentiation of hESCs (Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0001]) to HPCs can be performed with a variety of methods (Akopian et al., 2010[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-bib-0001]; Choi et al., 2011[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-bib-0004]; Crawford et al., 2021[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-bib-0005]; Kim et al., 2017[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-bib-0009]; Salvagiotto et al., 2011[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-bib-0020]). Here, we use defined commercial media and two distinct cytokine stimulation steps. First, hESCs are passaged, and early-stage (1-day post-passage) aggregates are induced to undergo a hematopoietic-endothelial transition beginning with differentiation to an endothelial-like adherent layer (days 1 to 3), followed by commitment to hematopoiesis (days 3 to 5) and finally further expansion of the hematopoietic population (days 6 to 12). After hematopoietic commitment and expansion, HPCs are harvested off the endothelial cell layer, collected, and washed, and then they can be used for downstream assays. This protocol is optimized to use one complete bottle of the STEMdiff Hematopoietic Kit to differentiate 15 wells of hESCs and yields ∼2 × 107 CD34+ HPCs. However, the entire protocol can easily be scaled down proportionally. An outline of the differentiation is shown in the last panel of Figure 1A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-fig-0001].
NOTE: At all steps, be careful not to disturb the aggregates by scratching with the pipet tip or by pipetting liquid onto the aggregate surfaces directly, and watch out for drying of exposed well surfaces during handling steps.

Preparation
1. Culture hESCs for at least two passages after thawing (see Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0001]).

2. Split cells, preparing two wells of hESCs for each batch to be used for differentiation (see Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0001]).
This is a normal passage of hESCs as described in Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0001] to maintain hESCs under normal growth conditions.
3. Feed and monitor hESCs as in Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0001], steps 22 to 33, until ready for passaging again.
hESCs should be split when aggregates are medium to large and ∼75% confluent-equivalent within the well, although the cells perform better when split the day before you would normally split for passage so that cells are in exponential growth but not senescent. Therefore, it is possible to plan differentiation experiments within a ∼2-day range but not exactly before the point of hESC split for differentiation.
Day –1: preparing and splitting cells
4. Prepare 15 wells in three separate 6-well tissue culture plates by coating with 1 ml prepared Matrigel solution (as in Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0001], steps 4 to 10 and steps 13 and 14).
Pre-grid the bottom of two wells for easier counting on day 0 by drawing lines ∼4 mm apart with an ultra-fine-point permanent pen. Each grid square should be visible on all sides under a 4× objective under a microscope, and the squares are simply guides to keep track of your location in the well when counting. Grid these two wells on two separate plates for replicate counts so cells are exposed to outside-incubator conditions for minimal possible time to minimize spontaneous differentiation and cell death due to handling. An example grid is shown in Figure 2B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-fig-0002], image 1.

5. Split hESCs using ReLeSR (see Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0001], steps 36 to 43) and plate on 6-well plates for a final (on day 0) aggregate density of about 200 aggregates per well (Fig. 1B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-fig-0001]; see Support Protocol 2[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0005] for counting aggregates).
This means that more aggregates are plated at this step to achieve an optimal concentration. For the author, 350 aggregates reliably result in 200 aggregates per well on the following day (day 0; see also Fig. 3A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-fig-0003]).
IMPORTANT NOTE: Aggregates must number between 100 and 300 per well on the next day to get optimal differentiation. Aggregate counting can vary between users, as does the total number of aggregates that remain at day 0 (Fig. 3A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-fig-0003]), and each individual user should empirically determine the best plating density using repeated small-scale differentiation batches (see also Troubleshooting in the Commentary).
6. Distribute aggregates evenly across the plate (see Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0001], step 21) and culture overnight.
7. Remove STEMdiff basal medium (from the STEMdiff Hematopoietic Kit) from the freezer and thaw at 4°C overnight.
Day 0: initial differentiation of aggregates
8. Count aggregates from each gridded well independently, storing all other plates in the incubator throughout counting.
9. Confirm that about 200 aggregates are present per well.
The number of aggregates present here at day 0 is generally reduced compared to the number plated at day –1 (see step 5 above), and each user should individually determine the survival rate to optimize to about 200 surviving aggregates per well at this step. It does not matter how many aggregates each user needs to plate at day 0 as long as the survival number is predictable (Fig. 3A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-fig-0003]).

IMPORTANT NOTE: If aggregates are widely different between wells, if aggregate counts are not appropriate (more or less than desired; Fig. 3B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-fig-0003]), or if aggregates are of poor quality (Fig. 1C[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-fig-0001]), stop here and set up a new batch of cells.
10. Prepare Medium A:
         
Retrieve STEMdiff basal medium from being thawed at 4°C overnight. If the medium is not completely thawed, place it temporarily at room temperature until all ice is gone. When the medium is thawed (do not let it warm up yet), proceed with steps 10b to 10g.
Remove Supplement A (from the STEMdiff Hematopoietic Kit) from −20°C ∼5 min before use.
Aliquot 45.5 ml STEMdiff basal medium to a 50-ml conical tube.
Vortex Supplement A and quick-spin.
Add 225 μl Supplement A (all of it) to the STEMdiff basal medium aliquot to make Medium A.
Return remaining STEMdiff basal medium to 4°C immediately.
Allow Medium A aliquot to come to room temperature before proceeding.
This protocol is for one batch (15 wells). If you are processing smaller batches, follow the manufacturer's instructions to aliquot supplements and media.
11. Remove all plates from the incubator.
This step involves a quick medium change only, so it is more practical to remove all the plates in one step to minimize opening/closing the incubator (and disturbing other cells), and the medium change is quick enough that this causes no harm to the current cells at this step.
12. Aspirate medium from one plate.
13. Immediately add 2 ml Medium A to each well.
14. Repeat steps 12 and 13 for remaining plates.
15. Return all plates to incubator and leave undisturbed.
16. Store remaining Medium A at 4°C until day 2.
Day 2: differentiation of aggregates, part 1
17. Warm Medium A to room temperature.

18. Remove plates from the incubator and check that aggregates are present and enlarged compared to day 0.
If the user is comfortable with aggregate analysis, all three plates can be handled in one batch, as the medium change is quick. If desired or if still learning analysis, each plate can be handled individually.
19. Remove 1 ml medium (half the well volume) from each well of one plate and discard.
20. Immediately add 1 ml fresh Medium A to each well.
21. Repeat steps 19 and 20 for all plates.
22. Return all plates to incubator and leave undisturbed.
Day 3: differentiation of aggregates, part 2
23. Prepare Medium B:
         
a.Remove Supplement B (from the STEMdiff Hematopoietic Kit) from −20°C ∼5 min before use.
b.Check that 75 ml STEMdiff basal medium remains.
This volume should remain because the manufacturer slightly overfills the bottle. If 45.5 ml was used in step 10c (from a listed total of 120 ml), there should be enough left for 15 wells.
You can keep the medium in the original bottle.
c.Vortex Supplement B and quick-spin.
d.Add 375 μl Supplement B (all of it) to STEMdiff basal medium to make Medium B.
This protocol is for one batch (15 wells). If you are processing smaller batches, follow the manufacturer's instructions to aliquot supplements and media.
24. Remove all plates from incubator and check that aggregates are present and enlarged compared to day 2.
25. Aspirate medium from each well of one plate.
26. Immediately add 2 ml Medium B to each well.
27. Repeat steps 25 and 26 for all plates.
28. Return all plates to incubator and leave undisturbed.
29. Store remaining Medium B at 4°C until needed.
Days 5, 7, and 10: differentiation of aggregates, part 3

30. Warm Medium B to room temperature.
31. Remove plates from the incubator and check that aggregates are differentiating.
32. Remove 1 ml medium (half the well volume) from each well of one plate and discard.
At days 7 and 10, remove only 0.9 ml medium from each well to account for evaporation, so that the final well volume is 1 ml old medium plus 1 ml new medium after the medium change.
A representative image of successful differentiation is shown in Figure 2A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-fig-0002].
33. Immediately add 1 ml fresh Medium B to each well.
34. Repeat steps 32 and 33 for all plates.
35. Return all plates to incubator and leave undisturbed.
36. Store remaining Medium B at 4°C until needed.
Day 12: harvest of HPCs
37. Warm DMEM/F12 medium to 37°C.
38. Set up 50-ml conical tubes to collect all harvested cells.
Cells are collected by supernatant removal and multiple wash steps (with a minimum of two 50-ml conical tubes per batch). The number of wash steps varies at step 43 depending on the degree of HPC attachment and user variability, so additional 50-ml conical tubes for collection are likely to be needed. Have extra tubes available and use as many as needed to collect all HPCs. The number of tubes used in steps 40 to 43 does not matter, as all cells will be combined at step 46.
39. Remove one plate from the incubator.
40. Harvest supernatant cells:
         
Using a 1-ml pipet tip, gently pipet supernatant around the first well a couple of times and transfer all medium plus floating cells to a 50-ml conical tube.
Add 2 ml warm DMEM/F12 to well.
Repeat steps 40a and 40b for all remaining wells on the plate.
Check that floaters and loosely attached cells are removed before proceeding.

Some HPCs naturally release into the supernatant or are very loosely attached to the aggregate. These are visible as suspension cells at this step (Fig. 2B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-fig-0002], image 2), and gentle, minimal pipetting force at this step removes these cells while protecting their viability before proceeding to dispersal of more firmly attached HPCs (see steps 41 to 43).
HPCs are attached to the surface of the aggregate to different degrees (Fig. 2A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-fig-0002]) and must all be removed. This is achieved by balancing trituration of attached cells with frequent removal of detached cells to preserve viability in steps 41 and 42.
41. Harvest attached hematopoietic cells (first round of detachment):
         
a.Pipet cells in one well gently but vigorously to break up (triturate; Fig. 2C[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-fig-0002]).
Go over every millimeter of the plate with the pipet ∼2 mm away from the surface, but not touching.
Minimize other wells/areas that are exposed to air by rotating the whole plate periodically.
b.Transfer cell suspension to a 50-ml conical tube.
c.Add 2 ml warm DMEM/F12 to the well.
d.Repeat steps 41a to 41c for all remaining wells in plate.
Check that attached hematopoietic cells are coming off but that the adherent layer remains intact (mature and budding HPCs vs. the hematopoietic-endothelial layer in Fig. 2A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-fig-0002]).
42. Harvest second set of attached hematopoietic cells (second round of detachment):
         
a.Pipet cells in one well gently but vigorously to break up (triturate).
Go over every millimeter of the plate with the pipet ∼2 mm away from the surface, but not touching.
Minimize other wells/areas that are exposed to air by rotating the whole plate periodically.
b.Transfer cell suspension to a 50-ml conical tube.
c.Add 2 ml DPBS to the well.
d.Repeat steps 42a to 42c for all remaining wells in plate.

Check that most of the attached hematopoietic cells are detached but that adherent cells are still attached (although likely lifting up).
43. Repeat step 42 (trituration and PBS coverage) as many additional times as needed until all hematopoietic cells are collected but minimal adherent cells are collected.
See Figure 2D[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-fig-0002], demonstrating remaining aggregates (hemato-endothelial layer) and removal of budded and mature HPCs.
44. Repeat steps 39 to 43 for all remaining plates.
45. Spin down all collected cells for 5 min at 300 × g at room temperature.
46. Pool all cells from the same batch (all three differentiation plates and all washes from steps 40 to 45) and resuspend in 25 ml DPBS.
47. Pass cells through a 70-μm nylon cell strainer into a new 50-ml conical tube to break up clumps.
48. Wash cell strainer with 5 ml DPBS to rinse all cells through.
49. Repeat wash in step 48 five times total.
The final volume should be 50 ml.
50. Spin down 5 min at 300 × g at room temperature.
51. Remove and discard supernatant.
52. Resuspend as appropriate for downstream assays:
         
For CD34 micro-bead isolation, resuspend all cells in 5 ml DPBS.
For FACS isolation, resuspend all cells in 1 ml DPBS.
For phenotyping all cells, resuspend in DPBS as in Support Protocol 3[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0006] or at 300 μl per original differentiation well.
For myeloid colony assays, resuspend at 106 cells in 1 ml IMDM without additives (see Basic Protocol 3[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0003]).
For other assays, resuspend in medium appropriate for the assay, usually 1 ml assay-specific medium (see also Basic Protocol 3[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0003] for long-term culture).

In steps 52a to 52e, the volume and type of medium used for resuspension depend on the number of wells harvested, the cell pellet size, and downstream applications. Some suggestions for a full batch of cells are described here.
53. Count using trypan blue to distinguish live versus dead cells.
Full differentiation will yield a mixture of HPCs (majority population) that should be ≥80% live plus a minor fraction of dead cells (<5%), endothelial cells (lifted from the adherent layer during harvest), and erythroid differentiating cells (that due to heme production can easily be miscounted as trypan blue positive). Differentiation success (and viability) can be measured by flow cytometry–based phenotyping using Support Protocol 3[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0006]. For troubleshooting the viability of differentiated cells, see Table 3[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-tbl-0003].

The main hallmarks of HPCs are long-term survival without differentiation (survival and self-renewal) and the ability to undergo directed, purposeful differentiation to their own specific downstream lineages (differentiation). This protocol outlines two different methods to test and validate HPC function following hESC-to-HPC differentiation (Basic Protocol 2[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0002]). The cells discussed here are HPCs and no longer hESCs. Here, we first use stromal cells to maintain and expand HPCs in vitro (Walenda et al., 2010[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-bib-0026]). Culturing HPCs on a feeder layer of bone marrow stromal cells for an additional 12 days allows measurement of long-term stem cell survival. Second, we use a classic method to assess the differentiation potential of HPCs to the myeloid lineage using a myeloid colony-forming assay (Bock, 1997[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-bib-0003]), which is used extensively to assess stem cell function and predict transplant success. In this assay, single HPCs are plated in semi-solid medium supplemented with cytokines and expand to clonal colonies differentiating to myeloid and erythroid lineages. Colonies are counted at 7 days (total initial survival), 14 days (total colonies and early differentiation), and 21 days (complete differentiation for hESC-derived HPCs).

Preparation
1. Obtain appropriate stromal cells for use in a stem cell feeder layer.
We use a 1:1 ratio of M2-10B4 and S1/S1 mouse stromal cells expressing human G-CSF and IL-3 maintained and passaged according to prior work (Umashankar & Goodrum, 2014[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-bib-0023]).
2. Coat one well of a 6-well tissue culture plate with 1 ml collagen solution for each group to be tested and incubate at room temperature for 2 min.
For smaller cell numbers for analysis, scale down the cell culture plate and cell numbers proportionally.
3. Remove collagen and allow plate to dry in the tissue culture hood for 1 hr.
4. Transfer stromal cells for irradiation in a secondary container and irradiate using a radiation source appropriate for cell lines.
For M2-10B4 and S1/S1, irradiate at 4 Gy.
5. Spin down cells in an appropriately sized tube for 5 min at 500 × g at room temperature. Aspirate supernatant and wash once with DPBS.

6. Wash collagen-coated wells from step 3 with 2 ml DPBS per well three times and aspirate off wash solution.
7. Add 1 ml stromal cell medium to each well.
8. Resuspend cells in 1 ml stromal cell medium per well and add to the plate.
For a 6-well plate containing M2-10B4 and S1/S1 at a 1:1 ratio, we use 1.5 × 105 cells of each cell type per well.
9. Incubate at 37°C overnight.
HPC culture
10. Obtain HPCs differentiated from hESCs, either immediately from harvest or further sorted (via FACS for specific phenotypic properties as desired), and resuspend in 2 ml/well complete MyeloCult containing 1 μM hydrocortisone. Plate at 5 × 104 to 2 × 105 cells/well.
11. Remove medium from the stromal cells and replace with 3 ml fresh complete MyeloCult containing 1 μM hydrocortisone.
12. Add transwells to the wells.
13. Add resuspended HPCs from step 10 (in 2 ml complete MyeloCult containing 1 μM hydrocortisone) to the top of the transwell.
14. Incubate at 37°C with 5% CO2.
15. Change medium every 4 days by removing 2 ml medium from beneath the transwell and replacing with fresh complete MyeloCult containing 1 μM hydrocortisone.
The medium on top of the transwell contains HPCs in suspension and should not be disturbed. The innate properties of a transwell will allow mixing of the fresh medium below the transwell with the medium on top of the transwell, providing new nutrients without disturbing the HPCs during culture.
HPC analysis
16. After 12 days in culture, pipet HPCs up and down to remove from the surface of the transwell and transfer to a 5- or 15-ml conical tube for analysis.

Analysis may include 1) counting the cells using trypan blue to assess viability and cell growth; 2) analyzing the cells by flow cytometry using Support Protocol 3[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0006] to assess phenotype, including stem cell markers; or 3) plating the cells for downstream differentiation (i.e., myeloid colony-forming assays, as in steps 17 to 24).
Cells can also be collected at desired time points (between plating and harvesting at 12 days) to track growth, survival, and stem cell properties over time. For cells that fail to survive during long-term culture, see Table 3[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-tbl-0003] for troubleshooting.
Myeloid colony-forming assays
Preparation
17. Thaw MethoCult SF H4436 at 4°C overnight.
Only MethoCult SF H4436 recapitulates viral (human cytomegalovirus, or HCMV)-induced myelosuppression with hESC-derived HPCs, a well-characterized and clinically relevant phenotype in HPCs, although multiple other media support myeloid colony formation alone from these cells (Crawford et al., 2021[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-bib-0005]).
There are multiple techniques for plating Methocult medium and cells to yield even dispersal of single cells throughout the well for accurate analysis. Descriptions and protocols can be found on the manufacturers’ websites, but our preferred methods (two options) are described in steps 20a and 20b.
18. Shake MethoCult vigorously to mix and allow bubbles to disperse.
19. Warm IMDM and DPBS to room temperature.
HPC plating
20a. Plating option 1: Prepare three replicate wells per condition:
         
i.Plate 1 ml MethoCult per well in a 6-well flat-bottom plate.
SmartDishes (specific 6-well flat-bottom plates) are required if using the STEMvision Analysis System. If counting manually, 6-well tissue culture dishes or individual 35-mm dishes can be used.
ii.Resuspend HPCs in 100 µl IMDM per intended well in a 1.5- or 2.0-ml snap-cap microcentrifuge tube.

HPCs from different sources have different differentiation potential, as measured by the number of colonies formed per initial number of HPCs plated in this assay (i.e., 1 colony to X initial HPCs). hESC-derived HPCs plated initially after harvest (without subsequent sorting for CD34+ cells) usually support colony formation at a plating density of 1:1000 to 1:5000 (or 104 cells per 1 ml Methocult). This is a reduction in colony-forming ability compared to that in cells from bone marrow (about 1:20 to 1:500 cells), cord blood (about 1:20 cells), and fetal liver (about 1:5 cells).
iii.Add 100 µl IMDM + cells to each well by evenly dispensing cells in a circle through the well. Start by dispensing cells with the pipet halfway between the edge and the center of the well and with the pipet halfway in the depth of the medium. Dispense cells evenly while moving the pipet in a circle within the well.
iv.Use the side of the pipet tip to mix the cells throughout the medium until all cells are spread equally throughout the well.
Plating option 1 requires only the number of cells needed for each replicate but requires more practice for even dispersal of single cells throughout the medium.
20b. Plating option 2: Prepare three replicate wells per condition:
         
Obtain N+1 volume of cells in IMDM for all replicates (e.g., for three replicates, 4× cells, or 400 µl cells, is needed).

HPCs from different sources have different differentiation potential, as measured by the number of colonies formed per initial number of HPCs plated in this assay (i.e., 1 colony to X initial HPCs). hESC-derived HPCs plated initially after harvest (without subsequent sorting for CD34+ cells) usually support colony formation at a plating density of 1:1000 to 1:5000 (or 104 cells per 1 ml Methocult). This is a reduction in colony-forming ability compared to that in cells from bone marrow (about 1:20 to 1:500 cells), cord blood (about 1:20 cells), and fetal liver (about 1:5 cells).
Add N+1 ml MethoCult to a 5- or 15-ml tube (depending on replicate number and availability; e.g., for three replicates, 4 ml MethoCult is needed).
Add cells to the medium.
Mix well by vortexing and allow bubbles to settle.
Plate 1.1 ml MethoCult + cells in each well of a 6-well flat-bottom plate.
SmartDishes (specific 6-well flat-bottom plates) are required if using the STEMvision Analysis System. If counting manually, 6-well tissue culture dishes or individual 35-mm dishes can be used.
Plating option 2 requires more cells and Methocult (to make a master mix) but less practice for even dispersal of single cells throughout the medium.
21. Check each well for bubbles and complete coverage with medium.
22. Place plates in a secondary container with open 35-mm dishes containing sterile water to maintain humidity and prevent drying of MethoCult.
23. Incubate at 37°C with 5% CO2.
Colony counting
24. Count colonies at 7, 14, and 21 days post-plating using the STEMvision System or a tissue culture microscope.

A valuable reference for colony types and counting can be found in the manuals from the main vendors (including STEMCELL Technologies), but note that colonies from hESCs are usually less abundant, more diffuse, and not quite typical in morphology compared to colonies from cord blood and bone marrow (and therefore do differ somewhat from the manuals’ images). Individual colony types from hESC-derived HPCs can be seen in Figure 4A from our original publication (Crawford et al., 2021[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-bib-0005]). For cells that fail to differentiate into myeloid cells, confirm proliferation ability using long-term culture (above) and/or see Table 3[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-tbl-0003] for troubleshooting.

Banked hESCs are essential for maintaining low-passage cells (required for appropriate differentiation) and a consistent lab stock of uniform cells. Cells currently (as of 2022) available from WiCell are shipped at passage 22 (WA01) or passage 26 (WA09). Although hESCs can be maintained in culture through more than 70 passages, pluripotency markers and gene expression stability change over time (Rosler et al., 2004[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-bib-0019]). This is especially relevant for downstream differentiation to hematopoietic lineages, as Choi et al. (2011[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-bib-0004]) recommend using cells no later than passage 50, and we have successfully used these hESCs for viral infection studies through passage 42 with no loss of function. This protocol outlines a robust serum-based freezing method to store cells where hESC aggregates are harvested from ideal growth conditions and cryogenically stored. Regardless of method, however, each batch of frozen hESCs varies slightly in recovery. The second part of this protocol outlines a process to empirically test frozen cell batches for viability, aggregate recovery, and aggregate condition using a plating dilution scheme and daily assessment.

Freezing medium (see recipe)

Freezing hESCs
1. Determine number of cryovials needed for freezing and pre-label.
Post-thaw recovery varies due to a number of factors, so each batch should be pre-tested for optimal plating density (see steps 12 to 33):
1) Controllable factors: freezing medium used, handling and processing time and conditions, time stored at −80°C, long-term storage conditions (liquid nitrogen storage).

2) Partially controllable factors (may vary between users): aggregate density, aggregate size, minor culture condition variations (e.g., temperature fluctuations or vibrations from others using the same culture incubator).
3) Partially controllable factors due to specific cell line, batch, and culture conditions: time in culture since last passage, passage number.
4) Uncontrollable factors: cell density within aggregates, overall cellular survival in culture.
Note that these factors are not necessarily problematic but should be considered when testing batches for reproducibility.
2. Warm complete mTeSR1 medium (0.5 ml per final vial plus 1 ml per well to harvest) to room temperature.
3. Passage hESCs as described in Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0001], steps 34 to 44, and collect all cells for this batch into one conical tube.
Use optimal and actively growing aggregates for freezing. Optimal aggregates are medium to large in size (500 to 1000 μm); are 70% to 80% confluent in the well, but with minimal aggregates touching each other; have even morphology, with minimal spontaneous differentiation and dense centers in the aggregate; and are at about 4 to 5 days after the previous split or 1 day before you would normally passage cells for maintenance growth.
A good starting point is to freeze one well of a 6-well plate of large aggregates that are 70% to 80% confluent in one freezing vial. This is very approximately 750 to 1000 aggregates per vial, although we routinely split by confluence equivalence rather than counted aggregates, as the time and additional handling required to count aggregates reduce frozen aggregate survival. More details of the thawing ratio and adjustments are provided in the testing section of this protocol (below).
4. Spin down for 5 min at 300 × g at room temperature.
5. Gently remove supernatant without disturbing the cell pellet.

Decant the supernatant and, keeping the tube upside down, blot on a Kimwipe/paper towel to drain remaining wash solution.
6. Gently resuspend cells in 0.5 ml complete mTeSR1 medium per final vial of frozen cells, taking care to avoid breaking up aggregates.
7. Slowly add an equivalent volume (0.5 ml per final vial) of freezing medium.
Freezing medium is used at a 1:1 ratio with normal growth medium (for hESCs, use complete mTeSR1) for final concentrations of 50% growth medium, 40% (v/v) serum, and 10% (v/v) dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO).
8. Invert tube gently to mix.
9. Aliquot 1 ml per cryovial.
10. Freeze in a controlled-rate freezing container at −80°C for 24 hr.
11. Transfer to liquid nitrogen for long-term storage.
hESCs are more sensitive than many cell types to long-term storage at −80°C and perform best if transferred to liquid nitrogen between 24 and 48 hr post-freezing.
Testing frozen batches of hESCs
12. For each vial of cells to be tested, coat four wells of a 6-well tissue culture plate with Matrigel as described in Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0001], steps 4 to 10.
13. Warm 9 ml complete mTeSR1 medium to room temperature.
14. Remove Matrigel solution from the plates and add 1 ml complete mTeSR1 medium to each of the four wells coated with Matrigel.
15. Label the wells as 1:2, 1:5, 1:10, and 1:100.
16. Add additional complete mTeSR1 medium to each well so that final volume will be 2 ml at the end of the protocol:
         
For 1:2 well, add 500 μl medium.
For 1:5 well, add 800 μl medium.
For 1:10 well, add 900 μl medium.
For 1:100 well, add 990 μl medium.

17. Thaw one vial of cells to be tested (see step 11) and wash with DMEM/F12 as described in Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0001], steps 15 to 18.
18. Resuspend in 1 ml complete mTeSR1 medium, mixing gently by pipetting.
19. Plate cells in the four pre-coated wells at different dilutions, starting with the lowest cell number (to avoid aggregate degradation from excessive mixing and to minimize inaccuracies due to settling of cells):
         
For 1:100 well, add 10 μl cells.
For 1:10 well, add 100 μl cells.
For 1:5 well, add 200 μl cells.
For 1:2 well, add 500 μl cells.
20. Place the plate back in the incubator, distribute aggregates evenly (see Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0001], step 21), and leave undisturbed for 24 hr.
21. Check cells the following day for attachment.
22. Change medium in all wells as described in Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0001], steps 22 to 28, and culture for an additional 24 hr.
23. Check cells the following day (day 2).
24. Determine well with the optimal aggregate conditions by assessing aggregate condition, aggregate size, and aggregate density as described in the Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0001] and Table 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-tbl-0001].
A representative image of good aggregate density, size, and condition is shown in Figure 1B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-fig-0001].
25. Double-check all wells the following day (day 3) and confirm optimal thaw ratio as in step 24 for this batch.
26. Change medium in all wells that contain reasonable numbers of aggregates.
Not all wells will be continued at this point. It is reasonable that, for example, the 1:2 dilution may well be too dense at this point (i.e., 50+% confluence) and/or that the 1:100 well may have no visible aggregates.
27. Culture cells for an additional 1 to 2 days and make a final determination of optimal thaw ratio depending on the aggregate density.

If the 1:100 well is optimal, then this batch should be thawed into 100 wells. If the 1:10 well is optimal, then this batch should be thawed into 10 wells. If the 1:5 well is optimal, then this batch should be thawed into 5 wells. If the 1:2 well is optimal, then this batch should be thawed into two wells. It is rare that the optimal density is outside of this range, but for specifics, see steps 29 to 33.
28. Optional: Continue culture (day 3 and onward) for optimal wells only, if desired, for additional expansion for banking or for an experiment. Change the medium on optimal well(s) daily as per normal culture protocols.
29. If the optimal density is close to ideal, but not ideal, then thaw future batches to the closest estimate.
For example, if the 1:5 well is only slightly under the optimal density, thaw this batch at a 1:3 to 1:4 ratio.
30. If the optimal density is between the larger values (e.g., somewhere between 1:10 and 1:100, where 1:10 is too crowded but 1:100 is too low), then re-test within this range.
Perform this step if the aggregate density does not match any of those mentioned in step 27.
31. If no aggregates are present in any well:
         
Incubate for an additional day and check again.
If no aggregates are present after 3 days, continue only 1:2 well for an additional 2 days to confirm.
If no aggregates are present, re-test batch at a 1:1 thaw (i.e., one vial to one well).

If no aggregates are present in a 1:1 thaw, this batch is not viable. Although it may be possible to recover this batch using a single-cell thaw protocol, this changes the cell properties, including phenotype and hematopoietic function. Thus, this batch should be discarded and a different batch used if at all possible.
32. If all wells are too dense, then estimate optimal thaw ratio as greater than 1:100 and update on next thaw or re-test using a 1:50, 1:100, 1:200, and 1:400 ratio.
The 1:50 is added and the 1:100 is repeated because it is very rare to have a 1:100 well that is too dense and because it is possible that either there was an error in diluting the cells to the plate or the vial used for the initial test thaw had an unusual clump of cells, giving it a higher aggregate number than the average vial in the batch. This method increases the chance of success on the second test.
33. As needed, if the ideal thawing ratio is routinely outside of one vial plated to between 2 to 20 wells, then adjust the freezing ratio for vials that are intended for experimental use, as relatively few wells are needed for scaling up cells for hematopoietic differentiation:
         
If recovery is routinely robust (e.g., one vial thaws into more than 20 wells), then increase freezing ratio to up to 2 to 3 vials per well to have a larger bank of lower-passage cells available.
If recovery of these cells is routinely low (e.g., if one vial consistently provides only one well of sparse aggregates, and handling and other conditions are correct), then scale up to freezing two wells per vial.

The optimal number of aggregates in a single well varies depending on the technique used and individual variations in maintenance, expansion, banking, and differentiation. Counting the number of aggregates is a method to more precisely control this variability and also provides an opportunity to more accurately estimate aggregate size, the number of cells per well, and aggregate condition. For example, aggregates at ≥50 μm in diameter are most likely to adhere and grow after splitting (or after freezing or during differentiation). However, aggregates at >100 μm at initial plating are more likely to have increased spontaneous differentiation during routine passage, may be less likely to thaw properly, and may have reduced differentiation capabilities. Aggregate count accuracy varies between individuals, in some instances dramatically; however, person-to-person variation is less of an issue if the following is true: intra-person variation is low (your own counts are consistent) and you have optimized the protocols (splitting and differentiation) for what works with your counts (or you have calibrated your counts to the standard). Here, we describe counting hESCs both by aggregate count, through simple harvest of aggregates (as performed for passaging cells) and manual counting in a gridded dish using a standard microscope, and via single-cell counting using enzymatic dissociation of aggregates and standard counting using a hemocytometer.

Trypan blue

Ultra-fine-point pen
Tissue culture microscope (inverted microscope with 4×, 10×, and 20× objectives; Nikon Ti2 or equivalent)

Counting hESC aggregates

1. Prepare three wells of a 96-well flat-bottom plate:
         
Grid the bottom of each well using an ultra-fine-point pen to draw guidelines ∼4 mm apart (or as needed for microscope) for counting.
Add 40 μl DMEM/F12 to each well.
2. Place 5 μl hESC aggregates released using ReLeSR in each of the three wells containing DMEM/F12.
Use a pipet tip no smaller than a P20 to avoid shearing aggregates.
3. Mix gently by tapping and allow aggregates to settle (about 3 to 5 min).
4. Count the total number of aggregates in each well that are ≥50 μm in diameter under a tissue culture microscope.
Optional: Count all aggregates of any size greater than four cells in the well. Keep small versus large aggregate counts separate.
5. Calculate total concentration of cell aggregates:
         formula:
$$\begin{eqnarray*} {\rm{Concentration}}\,{\rm{of}}\,{\rm{aggregates}}\,\left( C \right) &&= {\rm{average}}\,{\rm{number}}\,{\rm{of}}\,{\rm{aggregates/}}5\,{\rm{\umu l}}\nonumber\\ &&= {\rm{aggregates}}/{\rm{\umu l}} \end{eqnarray*}$$
6. Calculate total number of cell aggregates in the sample:
         formula:
$$\begin{equation*} {\rm{Total}}\,{\rm{aggregates}} = {\rm{C}} \times {\rm{total}}\,{\rm{volume}}\,\left( {{\rm{in}}\,{\rm{\umu l}}} \right) \end{equation*}$$
7. Determine target number of cell aggregates to plate.
Routine plating is between 350 and 1000 aggregates per well of a 6-well plate.
Plating for hematopoietic differentiation is less than for passaging, typically between 300 and 600 aggregates per well of a 6-well plate.
Total aggregates should be empirically determined for each user and assay (see Fig. 3[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-fig-0003]). Note that conditions are optimized for aggregate culture, so single cells and 2- to 5-cell aggregates, although viable at the time of passaging, do not survive.
8. Calculate total volume of cell aggregates to plate for each well of the experiment:
         formula:
$$\begin{equation*} {\rm{Volume}}\,{\rm{to}}\,{\rm{plate}}\,\left( {{\rm{in}}\,{\rm{\mu l}}} \right) = {\rm{desired}}\,{\rm{density}}/{\rm{C}} \end{equation*}$$
9. Continue with plating aggregates as desired (see Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0001], steps 34 to 46).
Counting single hESCs
10. Warm 0.5% trypsin/EDTA to room temperature.

11. Beginning with released hESCs, remove 50 μl aggregates and place in a 1.5-ml microcentrifuge tube.
Use a pipet tip no smaller than a P20 to avoid shearing aggregates.
12. Add 450 μl of 0.5% trypsin/EDTA solution to the tube and incubate at room temperature for 5 min to dissociate aggregates into single cells.
13. Add 1 ml DPBS and spin down 5 min at 400 × g at room temperature in a microcentrifuge.
14. Carefully remove all supernatant and resuspend cells in 50 μl DPBS.
15. Remove 20 μl resuspended cells and mix with 20 μl trypan blue.
16. Add 10 μl to each side of a standard hemocytometer.
17. Count total number of cells on each side of the hemocytometer under a tissue culture microscope and average the counts.
18. Calculate total concentration of cells:
         formula:
$$\begin{equation*} {\rm{Concentration}}\,{\rm{of}}\,{\rm{cells}}\,\left( C \right) = {\rm{average}}\,{\rm{number}}\,{\rm{of}}\,{\rm{cells}} \times 2 \times {10}^4 \end{equation*}$$
19. Calculate total number of cells in the sample:
         formula:
$$\begin{equation*} {\rm{Total}}\,{\rm{cells}} = {\rm{C}} \times {\rm{total}}\,{\rm{volume}}\,\left( {{\rm{in}}\,{\rm{\mu l}}} \right) \end{equation*}$$
20. Determine the target number of cells to plate depending on the downstream application.
21. Calculate the total volume of cells to plate for each well of the experiment:
         formula:
$$\begin{equation*} {\rm{Volume}}\,{\rm{to}}\,{\rm{plate}}\,\left( {{\rm{in}}\,{\rm{\mu l}}} \right) = {\rm{desired}}\,{\rm{density}}/{\rm{C}} \end{equation*}$$
22. Optional: To determine the average number of cells per aggregate, divide total number of cells from step 19 above by the total number of aggregates from step 6.
23. Gently mix remaining aggregate mixture (from step 11) by pipetting and plate as desired (see Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-prot-0001], steps 34 to 46).

Flow cytometry is a well-established method to phenotype cell populations based on their expression of various cell surface receptors. Here, we describe a standard protocol to stain HPCs with a viability dye and with fluorescently conjugated antibodies for progenitor cell markers and to fix the cells to accommodate biosafety concerns with human progenitors in shared flow cytometry facilities. These data can then be used to assess the differentiation success of each batch of cells in a short (∼3 hr) process.
NOTE: All centrifugation steps can be performed for 3 min at 500 × g at room temperature in 96-well plates (or for 5 min at 500 × g at room temperature in 5-ml polypropylene flow tubes). All supernatant is removed by decanting.

Recommended controls
1. Plan for recommended controls:
         
Negative controls: unstained samples, isotype-stained samples, and “true negative” stained samples (cells known to be negative for the selected marker).
Background fluorescence controls: unstained sample (one well) of each cell type.
FMO (fluorescent minus one) controls: one tube for each fluorophore used.
Viability controls: negative and positive viability dye controls.
Compensation controls as needed for the fluorophores used.
The recommended flow cytometry controls are for the specific protocol described below. Specific details on how to prepare and use these controls and flow cytometry best practices are outside the scope of this protocol but can be found in detail elsewhere, including basic techniques (Maecker & Trotter, 2006[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-bib-0013]), use of controls [including compensation (see Current Protocols article: Roederer, 2002a[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-bib-0017]) and FMO controls (see Current Protocols article: Roederer, 2002b[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-bib-0018])], and large-panel optimization (see Current Protocols article: Ferrer-Font et al., 2021[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.622#cpz1622-bib-0006]).
Viability staining and blocking
2. Plate HPCs and controls in 96-well plates.
3. Spin down and wash twice with DPBS.
4. Add 100 μl viability dye master mix to each sample and to positive viability dye control (see step 1).
Proteins (including serum) neutralize viability dye activity, so samples must be washed and stained in plain DPBS.
5. Incubate samples for 10 min at room temperature in the dark.
6. Set up compensation controls (see step 1).
7. Spin down cells and decant supernatant.
8. Wash cells twice with cold 1× FACS buffer (200 μl per well).

9. Decant off supernatant and resuspend cells in cold FACS blocking buffer (50 μl per well).
10. Incubate for 30 to 60 min at 4°C.
Surface antibody staining
11. Spin down cells and decant off supernatant.
12. Resuspend cells in cold staining solution (cold FACS blocking buffer + pre-titered antibodies; 50 μl per sample) or cold FACS blocking buffer alone as appropriate:
         
Staining solution: samples and stained controls (see step 1).
Blocking buffer only: unstained controls and background fluorescence controls (see step 1).
Other staining panels: isotype control and compensation (single-color) mixes (if compensating with stained cells instead of beads) (see step 1).
13. Stain cells for 30 to 60 min at 4°C in the dark.
14. Spin down cells and decant off supernatant.
Fixation
15. Resuspend cells in room-temperature FACS fixing buffer (100 μl/well).
16. Fix cells for 10 to 15 min at room temperature.
IMPORTANT NOTE: Do not reduce the fixing step to <10 min or increase it to >15 min.
17. Spin down cells and decant supernatant.
18. Wash cells twice in cold 1× FACS buffer (200 μl/well).
19. Resuspend in cold 1× FACS buffer (120 μl/well) and transfer to mini flow tubes.
20. Analyze samples using a flow cytometer.
